awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: vObjects - Understanding their Utility to Enhance Learning of Abstract and Complex Engineering Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
Thermodynamics is a subject that often features engineering problems that are not well-defined and abstract concepts that are often hard for students to understand. In addition, the scale at which thermodynamic phenomena occur makes it difficult, if not impossible, for students to interact with authentic physical objects that exhibit such phenomena. To address these challenges, this project will use virtual objects (vObjects) to enhance learning by closely mapping the learner experience to real-life engineering scenarios. This study will be one of the first to systematically evaluate characteristics and features of a virtual learning environment designed to support the "messiness" of real world problem solving.

This project will employ technological advancements for manipulation of vObjects to help students apply foundational knowledge to the solution of ill-defined problems and to address the improvement of virtual learning for future engineering curricula. A comprehensive understanding of the utility of vObjects in engineering will contribute to the development of online learning environments, including augmented reality environments. Virtual learning of engineering skills can also be used as a tool for broadening participation in STEM by providing the opportunity for greater access by diverse students. In broad terms, this research will contribute to improving and transforming undergraduate engineering education by enhancing student learning of theoretical and abstract engineering concepts.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Today's era of exponential technology expansion and new demands, like online education, which accommodates more with the fast-paced life, are emphasizing on the importance of adjustments in educational practice. The impact of utilizing a specially designed "Virtual-Object" and project-based learning instruction in the Thermodynamics course on engineering students' performance was investigated. Additionally, to underline the importance of the evaluation method, and to identify the preferred one based on the learning goal, Rubric-based grading, and Quantitative data analysis were used as two different evaluation methods.

The statistical analyses with both evaluation methods showed a significant improvement in the performance of students in an identical project when the V-object had been used by the students. The virtual environment intuitively helps the students to have a better-visualized experience on the course materials. Furthermore, the content analyzing method provided more detailed information and showed the considered aspects by students of each class are not following the general rules, and some small and unexpected variations can be seen in the final results. 

In comparing two different analyzing methods in this study, it is clear that quantitative content analysis provided more detailed information based on the idea and arguments of the students when their cognitive or practical skills being evaluated. However, it is probably not a preferred method in the analysis of recalling the predefined data. By coordinating these findings with revised Bloom's taxonomy, it could be concluded that content analysis is the preferred method in project-based learning when we want to evaluate the "evaluating and creating" the highest levels of learning goals, but it is not a good method when we are analyzing the basic levels of learning like remembering. Moreover, the researcher can evaluate the weakness and strengths of his/her project by investigating the results of each category and use them in future studies. Although the results obtained from quantitative content analysis were mainly in agreement with the rubric-based grading results, the finding of this study underlines the importance of the evaluation method and suggests that analyzing methods should be selected prudently based on the specific learning goals of the study.

 

Broader Impact:

The use of newly developed technologies is becoming an inseparable aspect of higher education. In the engineering field, which is the combination of analytical thinking, designing skills, and creativity, it is critical to utilize the advanced technologic methods and have the evolutionary process to help the learning ability of students. Thermodynamics is one of the most present sciences in daily life, but many students find the thermodynamics course complicated because of its abstract feature, which includes different topics and their relation either theoretically or numerically. Using the concepts of vObject engineering students can gain a better understanding and be better prepared for their professional life.

The use of vObjects can be used in courses in other disciplines to improve project-based learning.  The concept can be extended to virtual laboratory and design courses in engineering.

The vObjects has the opportunity to provide active learning and experiential learning during times when face-to-face student instruction maybe restricted or financially not feasible.
